bibl.title: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, April 2, 1942

div1.p: Ames answers Hench's questions concerning her husband's role at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, April 2, 1942
div1.opener:
The Southern Frontier
ISSUED BY
COMMISSION ON INTERRACIAL COOPERATION, INCORPORATED
710 STANDARD BUILDING
ATLANTA, GEORGIA
April 2, 1942
MRS. JESSIE DANIEL AMES
MANAGING EDITOR
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In preparing the report of my husband's record I did not, as
you may have noticed, put in anything for which I had only my
husband's words. He did tell me some things about Camp
Lazear, but you see that had I used his stories as the basis
of my report, it would have resolved itself into my recollections
of his spoken words against the word of a living man, Dr. Kean,
who was in a position of authority.

item.p:
1- Dr. Ames was in charge of Camp Lazear. The supporting evidence
is found in the record where I quoted the New Orleans Picayune
of July 30, 1905. Part of the news story is not included for
I did not think it applicable to the point I was making. The
story further stated that there was great excitement the night
my husband phoned to Dr. Reed at Columbia Barracks that the
first experimental case, Kissinger, mosquito infected, had de-
veloped fever. To Dr. Reed's question as to whether or not
Dr. Ames was sure it was the fever, he was assured that it was.
I haven't a copy of the Picayune of this date but if you would
like to have the exact words I can get a cousin of Roger's in
New Orleans to go down and copy the whole story. I felt reason-
ably sure that the story was true, and still do, for at that
time Dr. Kean was in the Surgeon General's office in Washington
and had Roger made a misstatement of fact, he would have been
rebuked either by Dr. Kean or Colonel Maus from San Antonio.
The story bears out Roger's own account of sleeping at Camp
Lazear. In addition to this story I have a letter from Dr. Kean
dated December 9, 1929, a copy of which I am sending you, in
which he states that because they thought Roger was an immune,
he was “selected to be in charge of the personnel of Camp Lazear.”

2- It seems to me, and this aside from the things my husband told
me, that with no member of the Board in attendance at Camp Lazear,
my husband, a surgeon in the employ of the Army and admittedly
an expert in diagnosis and treatment of a disease which was being
experimented on, would not have been made “administrator” of personnel
-2-
with no other duties. Roger never said that he was alone with the men at
Camp Lazear but he never spoke of another doctor. It was this ommission
which made me press Dr. Kean and General Ireland for the names of some
other doctors there. To support my statement that none of the Board was
at Camp Lazear I refer you to page 20 of Dr. Agramonte's pamphlet beginning
with sentence “After the case of Dean.....”

One part of the story of this “Great Medical Discovery” which I have not
mentioned for it has no bearing on my husband's work is that dealing with
the attitude of the three groups of experimental cases. Since my husband
did not doubt that yellow fever was carried by mosquitoes and could be
contracted in no other method, he spoke frequently of the fears of the men
who submitted to the bed linen tests. He considered them the real heroes of
the times because they believed that they would contract the disease
while the mosquito infected cases, at least in the beginning, took it all as
something of a lark. Later they were a bit more fearful but as no patients
died of the fever their fears were not so great as those who slept in the beds
with the supposedly infected bed linen. My husband had something of a grim
sense of humor which he displayed in talking about this part of the experiment.

The occasion for speaking of this part of the story came up more frequently
than any other as the move for individual pensions began long before my
husband's death. It was his opinion that no permanent disability followed
yellow fever. He may have been mistaken. He did think it highly amusing
that the cases should consider themselves heroes after the fact when at the
time they were not impressed by their own fortitude.

There is much more that I could tell of our conversation on Cuba but there
is no point in doing so as they did not relate to the professional side of
his work.

list.item:
2- This question of my husband's case of fever has been one that has annoyed
the Department and Dr. Kean more than any other. I am sending you a copy
of Dr. Kean's letter to me in which he speaks of the alleged case of fever
and his not knowing anything about it. I am also sending you copies of
correspondence between General Ireland and Senator Sheppard showing that
this was not included in Roger's record and that it was finally put in only
upon Senator Sheppard's insistence. In fact, as I think I have written you,
the fact that Roger was not an immune but did take over the Camp seems to have
created a most unfavorable reaction to Roger personally. His chart incidentally
shows that he was sick somewhere or other for nine days instead of the three
or four days of which Dr. Kean spoke. Viewed in the light of the attitude
of the Board members in the document of Dr. Agramonte his act of devotion shows
up rather well. I think that his case of fever was deliberately suppressed
for this reason.

3- I have looked for the map referred to by Dr. Reed. I concluded at length that
it was later turned over to the War Department as part of the records. Now
-3-
that you write you could not find it there, I shall explore the only place
left. I will let you know, as soon as I do, whether or not it turns up.
I know that the making of such a map was Roger's idea. He was a man of
some few fixed ideas in his profession. One of these was this thing of
having a map made of an infected community and the taking of copious
daily notes on the location of every reported case, proven or suspected.
He either insisted on a hospital orderly who could draw or on the
employment of a civilian who could do the work. He did not always have
the cooperation of his superiors in this. I do not have the case histories
of the patients. However, recently I have found out that my husband's
sister has a great many of his papers and I shall try to get hold of them.
If by chance there are any of these or the map among the papers I will
let you know at once.

4-You know, I never noticed the “Dr. James” reference until you called my
attention to it. Raising three children from scratch appears to have dulled
my perception for details. I never heard Roger speak of a Dr. James. I
can't clear this up for you.

5-My husband did not write articles or a book on his experiences in Cuba. I
should only be guessing if I gave any reasons for this omission. It is a
pity now that he did not, isn't it?

6-I am sending you another picture of Roger which you may keep. It was taken
around about the late fall or early winter of 1900 I am sure. It was before
he was made a captain for his collar does not carry the “V” and his shoulder
shows, I think, one bar though there may not be any.

7-There was no notation on the back of the group picture. I have a mounted
copy which carried nothing on it. It was taken at the time of the picture
I am sending you. Mr. Lambert wrote me that he either showed or gave you
a picture taken at the time of the experiments. I do not know which one
that would be. If it were one without a moustache that would not indicate
that it was not taken at the same time.

8-I am sending you the clinical chart of Private Kissinger. I have all those
on the list attached to the additional data I am sending you. If you want
them, too, let me know and I will send them on. I am leaving for Texas the
10th and will be gone until the first Monday in May. If you want them
before I get back, let me know.

9-I have no copy of the book to which you refer. It strikes me that the
Medical Department of the Army is or was somewhat casual in the handling of
its documents.
10-The copies of the record and other data are included herewith.

11-Copies of the correspondence are also included together with other letters.
When your letter came I decided to dig into my own files - I had used only
Roger's for the most part - and see whether or not something else might
be found which would help you. This accounts for the correspondence between
me and Dr. Kean and the rest. Also, I found the account of my interview with
Dr. Kean. I was sure I had refused to write it out even though Dr. White
insisted that I do so. In reading it over, however, I do see that I softened
it considerably. His, Dr. Kean's, flattery of me with which he interlarded
his discourse, is omitted entirely for obvious reasons. Besides it sickened
me.

12-I am not surprised that the lower ring on the book has sprung. It is an old
one, originally a zippered portfolio, and has seen quite heavy use. I have
plenty transparent envelopes so don't pay this any mind. I have no doubt
you are careful of the contents. Most doctors are careful.

12-I used the word “innoculation” by mistake. I was referring to mosquito
infection which my husband did carry out. I do not recall his speaking of
innoculating any case so someone else undoubtedly performed that service.

13-Dr. Agramonte sent me a copy of his privately printed pamphlet. I have all
the pamphlets which I listed.

item.p:
14-I have nothing you speak of in this item. I may be able to get some Havana
newspapers of that period from a cousin there. His father, my uncle, was one
of the few civilian cases my husband treated.

I have had to use my judgment in selecting the material I have sent you. Had
I sent you everything without selection, you would have been overwhelmed by
the quantity. What I have omitted seemed to me trivial or not applicable to
an extent sufficient to justify inclusion. But if there should be something
else upon which you need a little light thrown I will help if I can.

I am interested in having the work of Dr. Roger Port Ames objectively evaluated
for the sake of his three children who never knew their father. I think that
your judgment will be accepted by them as fair and just. They are completely
free of any psychological twist in reference to him, a condition achieved by
the exertion of much self-control on my part.

I am surprised that you stumbled on Roger and his record at all though I, too,
wish it had been before your visit to Atlanta last year.

div1.closer:
Very cordially yours, Jessie Daniel Ames X I find I have left the copies of the Andrus'
letters and the others at home- I will mail them
to you tomorrow J D A.
